strikes.leader_names: Saleh al-Tays al-Waeli; Saleh Ali Guti
strikes.leaders_desc: Waeli was on a government list of 25 al-Qaeda suspects wanted in connection with an alleged plot to launch a major attack before Ramadan ended and the Muslim Eid al-Fitr feast began

strikes.notes: A child was reported killed in this strike. He was identified as 10-year-old Abdulaziz, whose older brother Saleh Hassan Huraydan was the apparent target.
Reports indicate that two drones struck two vehicles, but because the reports do not break down the casualty figures for the two strikes, we have counted this as one strike.

strikes.leader_names: Abd Rabbo Mokbal Mohammed Jarallah al-Zouba; Abbad Mossad Abbad Khobzi

strikes.notes: The strike hit an explosives-laden truck and killed all four suspected al-Qaeda militants inside. According to the Yemen Times, there were rumors that prominent AQAP leader Jamal Bl'eed was killed in the attack, but his family denied these rumors.
Xinhua reported that the strike was a joint military operation by U.S., Yemeni, and Saudi intelligence services.
According to Reuters, the house was used to train AQAP members and a cache of weapons was found there.
Xinhua reported that the drone appeared to target a motorbike, but missed, striking a house instead and killing two children.
Yemen Observer reported that one civilian was killed, prompting protests from local Khawlan tribesmen.

strikes.leader_names: Ahmed al-Ziadi; Qasem Naser Tuaiman; Ali Saleh Tuaiman
strikes.leaders_desc: Ziadi was a suspected AQAP leader in Marib; the Tuaimans were militants freed by Yemeni authorities in April 2012 after several months in prison

strikes.notes: Ismail bin Jamil, a Saudi national, was identified as one of the dead.

strikes.leaders_desc: Chief architect behind a 2011 mass prison break that freed dozens of fighters
Wanted for 2008 bombing of U.S. Embassy in Sanaa

strikes.notes: This was the first report of an attack by a pilotless plane in the area near the Saudi border in northern Yemen.

strikes.leaders_desc: One of the top al-Qaeda leaders in the region

strikes.leader_names: Fahd Saleh al-Anjaf al-Harithi; Hassan Ali al-Ishaqi

strikes.notes: Xinhua post claims that 3 militants, including a senior militant commander, were killed by a US drone strike in Aden. According to Xinhua, the drone hit a small pick-up truck. Yemen Post says that there is no confirmation about how many people died and quotes BBC on this. It also states that the drone hit two vehicles rather than a pick-up truck.

Security officials told CNN that at least 14 drone strikes were carried out over the previous two days. Reporting on U.S. drone strikes has been difficult with the Yemeni military simultaneously waging an air and ground war on suspected al-Qaeda militants.

strikes.leaders_desc: Local al-Qaeda leader, brother-in-law to Anwar al-Awlaki
strikes.notes: A U.S. drone strike targeted a convoy of vehicles, one of which was carrying local al-Qaeda leader Qaid al-Dahab. But a tribal source told the AFP that al-Dahab, whose sister is the widow of Yemeni-American cleric Anwar al-Awlaki, survived the attack.

The Yemen Post reported that local sources differed on whether the missile in this attack was fired from a U.S. drone or from a ship off of Yemen's coast. Meanwhile, Reuters reported only that it was an "air strike" without providing any further details.

Reports did not specify which country carried out this air strike, but the fact that the missiles hit a vehicle may indicate that the source was a US drone. The Yemeni Air Force is not thought to have the capability to strike a moving target.
Although most news outlets reported the strike just as a general air strike, CNN reported that many locals suspected it was a U.S. drone strike.
Local officials said the suspected drone attack took place near the border of Shabwa and Maarib Provinces.

strikes.leaders_desc: Militant in charge of armaments for AQAP
Senior al-Qaeda leaders; Quso was convicted for playing a role in bombing of USS Cole
strikes.notes: The Yemeni embassy in Washington stated that Fahd al-Quso was one of the leaders of AQAP and one of Yemen's most wanted terrorists. The other person in the car was identified by residents as Fahed Salem al-Akdam.

Reports did not specify which country carried out this air strike, but the fact that the missiles hit a vehicle may indicate that the source was a US drone. The Yemeni Air Force is not thought to have the capability to strike a moving target.
This drone strike was reported by only one source.

strikes.notes: This was the first CIA drone strike in Yemen since 2002. All previous strikes were carried out by the military's Joint Special Operations Command or were cruise missiles launched from U.S. Navy vessels off the Yemeni coast.

strikes.sources: Long War Journal: <http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2010/05/yemeni_airstrike_kil.php>  NYT: <http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/26/world/middleeast/26yemen.html>  Reuters: <http://uk.reuters.com/article/2010/05/25/uk-yemen-idUKTRE64O17W20100525>  WSJ: <http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203899504577126883574284126.html>  Yemen Observer: <http://www.yobserver.com/front-page/10018779.html>

strikes.notes:
The airstrikes were aimed at a large group of Qaeda operatives who had gathered in the southern province of Shabwa to plan attacks against the Yemeni government in retaliation for an offensive the week before, the Yemeni Embassy statement said.

Yemeni officials said they had made targets of the leader of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, Nasser al-Wuhayshi, and his deputy, Said Ali al-Shihri, who were believed to be at the meeting with Mr. Awlaki.  The Yemeni Embassy in Washington D.C. released a statement on December 24, 2009 saying, " "Today, Yemeni fighter jets launched an aerial assault at 4:30 a.m., on a remote location in the province of Shabwa." Other reports indicated that the strike was actually carried out by a U.S. cruise missile. The United States said it only provided intelligence, while Yemen denied involvement altogether. A diplomatic cable released by Wikileaks appears to indicate that it was indeed a U.S. strike, but it remains unclear what form the attack took.

Six months after this strike took place, Amnesty International released images of U.S.-made cluster bombs that had purportedly been fired by American naval vessels during this attack. Amnesty also reported that 55 people had been killed in the strike, 41 of whom were civilians -- mostly women and children.
strikes.sources: ABC: <http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/cruise-missiles-strike-yemen/story?id=9375236&page=2#.TtUczV1AIj8>  Amnesty: <http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/yemen-images-missile-and-cluster-munitions-point-us-role-fatal-attack-2010-06-04>  AJE: <http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2010/06/20106653442608341.html>   BBC: <http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10251954>  Fox: <http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/12/18/launched-missile-strikes-al-qaeda-yemen-sources-say/>  NYT: <http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/18/world/middleeast/18yemen.html>   NYT: <http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/19/world/middleeast/19yemen.html>

strikes.leader_names: Qaed Salim Sunian al-Harithi; Kamal Derwish
strikes.leaders_desc: Harithi was al-Qaeda's chief operative in Yemen and a suspect in the bombing of the USS Cole; Derwish was an al-Qaeda operative
strikes.notes: Kamal Derwish, an American citizen, was killed in the attack.  He is the first known U.S. citizen to be killed by the United States abroad.
